Submodules

quask.datasets module

Module dedicated to the generation and retrieval of classical and quantum datasets.

param the_dataset_register

singleton global instance of DatasetRegister

class quask.datasets.DatasetRegister[source]

Bases: object

List of datasets available in this module. The object is iterable.

register(dataset_name, dataset_type, information_nature, get_dataset)[source]

Register a new dataset.

Parameters

  • dataset_name – name of the dataset

  • dataset_type – ‘regression’ or ‘classification’

  • information_nature – ‘classical’ or ‘quantum’

  • get_dataset – function pointer to a zero-parameter function returning (X, y)

Returns

None

quask.datasets.download_dataset_openml(the_id)[source]

Download a dataset from OpenML platform given the ID of the dataset.

Parameters

the_id – ID of the dataset (int)

Returns

tuple (X, y) of numpy ndarray having shapes (d,n) and (n,)

quask.datasets.download_dataset_openml_by_name(name)[source]

Download a dataset from OpenML platform given the name of the dataset

Parameters

name – name of the dataset (str)

Returns

tuple (X, y) of numpy ndarray having shapes (d,n) and (n,)

quask.datasets.get_dataset_quantum(the_id)[source]

This function calls already preprocessed datasets with quantum labels. These examples are identified with a specific id.

The available datasets at the moment are:

  • Fashion-MNIST with 2 features and encoding E1

  • Fashion-MNIST with 4 features and encoding E2

  • Fashion-MNIST with 8 features and encoding E3

These datasets can be used to benchmark the performace of our classical and quantum kernels to verify the power of data.

Parameters

the_id – parameter able to distinguish between quantum dataset

Returns

tuple (X, y) of numpy ndarray having shapes (d,n) and (n,)

quask.kernels module

Module dedicated to the applying classical and quantum kernel on the given datasets.

param the_kernel_register

singleton global instance of KernelRegister

class quask.kernels.KernelRegister[source]

Bases: object

List of datasets available in this module. The object is iterable.

register(fn, name, params)[source]

Register a new kernel.

Parameters

  • fn – function pointer to a kernel function having exactly three parameters: X_1, X_2 numpy training and testing Gram matrices, and a possibly empty list of parameters

  • name – name of the kernel (str)

  • params – list of parameters (List[str])

Returns

None

quask.metrics module

Module dedicated to study the Gram matrices generated with the quantum kernels.

quask.metrics.calculate_approximate_dimension(k)[source]

Calculate the approximate dimension (d), which is equation S111 in the Supplementary of the “The power of data in quantum machine learning” (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-22539-9).

Parameters

k – Kernel gram matrix.

Returns

approximate dimension of the given kernel (float).

quask.metrics.calculate_frobenius_inner_product(A, B, normalized=False)[source]

Calculate the Frobenius inner product of two matrices.

Parameters

  • A – first matrix (numpy ndarray)

  • B – second matrix (numpy nodarray)

  • normalized – if True the result is divided by its norm

Returns

Frobenius inner product (float)

quask.metrics.calculate_generalization_accuracy(training_gram, training_labels, testing_gram, testing_labels)[source]

Calculate accuracy wrt a precomputed kernel, a training and testing set

Parameters

  • training_gram – Gram matrix of the training set, must have shape (N,N)

  • training_labels – Labels of the training set, must have shape (N,)

  • testing_gram – Gram matrix of the testing set, must have shape (M,N)

  • testing_labels – Labels of the training set, must have shape (M,)

Returns

generalization accuracy (float)

quask.metrics.calculate_geometric_difference(k_1, k_2, normalization_lambda=0.001)[source]

Calculate the geometric difference g(K_1 || K_2), which is equation F9 in “The power of data in quantum machine learning” (https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01938) and characterize the separation between classical and quantum kernels.

Parameters

  • k_1 – Quantum kernel Gram matrix

  • k_2 – Classical kernel Gram matrix

  • normalization_lambda – normalization factor, must be close to zero

Returns

geometric difference between the two kernel functions (float).

quask.metrics.calculate_kernel_polarity(gram_matrix, label_vector)[source]

Calculate the kernel polarity.

Parameters

  • gram_matrix – data points (square) Gram matrix (numpy ndarray)

  • label_vector – label vector (numpy ndarray)

Returns

Kernel polarity.

quask.metrics.calculate_kernel_target_alignment(gram_matrix, label_vector)[source]

Calculate the kernel-target alignment.

Parameters

  • gram_matrix – data points (square) Gram matrix (numpy ndarray)

  • label_vector – label vector (numpy ndarray)

Returns

Kernel-target alignment (float).

quask.metrics.calculate_model_complexity(k, y, normalization_lambda=0.001)[source]

Calculate the model complexity s(K), which is equation F1 in “The power of data in quantum machine learning” (https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01938).

Parameters

  • k – Kernel gram matrix

  • y – Labels

  • normalization_lambda – Normalization factor

Returns

model complexity of the given kernel

quask.template_pennylane module

Module dedicated to define Templates for Pennylane quantum circuits. See https://pennylane.readthedocs.io/en/stable/introduction/templates.html for details.

class quask.template_pennylane.PennylaneTrainableKernel(X_train, y_train, X_test, y_test, embedding, var_form, layers, optimizer, metric, seed, keep_intermediate=True)[source]

Bases: object

Create a trainable kernel using Pennylane framework.

Parameters

(fn, n) tuple of function and integer, the former representing the ansatz and the latter the number of parameters

quask.template_pennylane.ltfim_ansatz(theta, wires)[source]

Transverse Field Ising Model with additional sigma_z rotations. Figure 6a (right) in https://arxiv.org/pdf/2105.14377.pdf

Parameters

  • theta – parameter vector (list or numpy array of floats)

  • wires – wires of the circuit (list of int)

Returns

None

quask.template_pennylane.pennylane_projected_quantum_kernel(feature_map, X_1, X_2=None, params=[1.0])[source]

Create a Quantum Kernel given the template written in Pennylane framework.

Parameters

  • feature_map – Pennylane template for the quantum feature map

  • X_1 – First dataset

  • X_2 – Second dataset

  • params – List of one single parameter representing the constant in the exponentiation

Returns

Gram matrix

  • X – feature data (matrix)

quask.template_pennylane.random_qnn_encoding(x, wires, trotter_number=10)[source]

This function creates and appends a quantum neural network to the selected encoding. It follows formula S(116) in the Supplementary.

Parameters

  • x – feature vector (list or numpy array of floats)

  • wires – wires of the circuit (list of int)

  • trotter_number – number of repetitions (int)

Returns

None

quask.template_pennylane.rx_embedding(x, wires)[source]

Encode the data with one rotation on sigma_x per qubit per feature

Parameters

  • x – feature vector (list or numpy array of floats)

  • wires – wires of the circuit (list of int)

Returns

None

quask.template_pennylane.rz_embedding(x, wires)[source]

Encode the data with one hadamard then one rotation on sigma_y per qubit per feature

  • wires – wires of the circuit (list of int)
